conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time.
On a v-t graph, acceleration is represented by the slope of the curve.
Positive slope means positive acceleration.
Negative slope means negative acceleration.
The steepness of the slope indicates the magnitude of acceleration.
Object A follows the upper curve which appears to be parabolic.
At t = 0, the curve for Object A starts with zero velocity and a positive slope.
As time progresses for Object A, the slope increases initially indicating increasing acceleration.
After reaching a point of inflection, the slope for Object A starts decreasing indicating decreasing acceleration.
Near t₁, the slope for Object A becomes zero at the peak indicating acceleration becomes zero.
Object B follows the lower curve which also appears to be parabolic but with a smaller amplitude.
At t = 0, the curve for Object B starts with zero velocity and a positive slope.
Similar to Object A, the slope for Object B appears to increase initially indicating increasing acceleration.
After some point, the slope for Object B starts decreasing indicating decreasing acceleration.
Near t₁, the slope for Object B becomes zero at the peak indicating acceleration becomes zero.
Both objects' accelerations first increase then decrease as indicated by the slopes of their curves.
If a v-t curve is concave up, acceleration is increasing.
If a v-t curve is concave down, acceleration is decreasing.
Both curves appear to start concave up indicating increasing acceleration.
Both curves transition to concave down indicating decreasing acceleration.
Final answer: Yes, the accelerations of both objects A and B first increase and then decrease during the time interval from 0 to t₁.
